questions.text: An 18 year old boy got frost bite of left feet after working in a snowy feld for 5-6 hours. He complained of paln, numbness and limited moment of his toes. The skin appeared white and waxy. Which one of the tollowing Is contradicted as initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Massage Explanation: Freezing cold injury or frostbite/ trench foot or immersion injury ? Vasoconstriction, ice formation and freezing within the tissue, most commonlv afecting the hands and feet (around 90% of cases). Risk factors incude alcohol, previous frostbite, drug use, inappropriate clothing, fatigue and dehydration. Tissue injury results trom both treezing and vasoconstriction. ? Superficial frostbite involves the skin and subcutaneous tissue. Pain or paresthesia, and the skin appear white and waxy. After rewarming there Is cyanosis and erythema, wheal-and-flare formation, edema, and superficial blisters. Deep frostbite involves muscle, nerves, and deeper blood vessels. It may result in edema of the hand or foot, vesicles and bullac, tissue necrosis, and gangrene. ? Treatment:- Consume warm drinks, remove shoes, wet clothing and jewellery and re-dress in warm, dry cothing. Re-freezing tollowing warming is particularly destructive; therefore re-warming should only be initiated if there is no risk of further re-freezing. Rewarming by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 40°-44°c (004°-1u°F), IV warm fluid fluids (due to cold diuresis), strong analgesia and blister care. Massage, application of ice water, and extremne heat are contraindicated. Area should be cleansed with soap or antiseptic and sterile dressings should be applied. Analgesics (Aspirin 75-300 mg and ibuprofen 800 mg) are often required during rewarming Antibiotics are used if there is evidence of infection. Combination of thrombolvsis and vasodilators (such as nitroglycerin), given within 24 hours in hospital. iloprost, a Prostacyclin analogue reduce chance of amputation Pernio (Chilblains) ? Vasculitic disorder associated with exposure to cold; acute forms have been described. Raised erythematous lesions develop most commonly on the toes or fingers in cold weather and are associated with pruritus and a burning sensation; may blister and ulcerate. ? Pathologic examination demonstrates angitis characterized by intimal proliferation and perivascular infiltration of mononuclear and polymorphonuclear leukocytes. ? Treatment: - Sympatholytic drugs and dihydropyridine calcium channel antagonists. Avoid exposure
to cold, and ulcers should be kept clean and protected with sterile dressings.

3. Glucocorticoids 
4. Mineralocorticoids
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 1, 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: Most leg swelling is caused by oedema.
Mechanisms for the development of oedema are: ? Increased hydrostatic pressure in the venous
system due to increased intravascular volume or venous obstruction ? Decreased oncotic pressure
secondary to a decrease in the plasma proteins that retain fluid within the circulation ? Obstruction to
lymphatic drainage (lymphoedema) Causes of peripheral oedema ? Cardiac failure: right or combined
left and right heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, pericardial constriction, cardiomyopathy ?
Chronic venous insufficiency: varicose veins, DVT ? Hypoalbuminaemia: nephrotic syndrome, liver
disease, protein losing enteropathy ? Drugs: Calcium channel blockers (Increasing capillary
permeability). glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, fludrocortisone, NSAIDs. dihydropyridine and
thiazolidinediones ? Idiopathic: women > men ? Chronic lymphatic obstruction ; myxedema caused
by hypothyroidism or pretibial myxedema associated with Graves' disease ? Gastrocnemius muscle
tear (which may be traumatic or spontaneous) or a ruptured Bakers cyst, lower limb injury
(hematoma)

Left atrial dilatation on X-ray chest is characterised by which of the following? 
1. Straight left heart border 
2. Rounding of left heart border 
3. Double cardiac shadow 
4. Widening of the angle of carina
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 1, 3 and 4 Explanation: Cardiomegaly can be caused by chamber
dilatation, especially left ventricular dilatation, or by a pericardial effusion, but may also be due to a
mediastinal mass or pectus excavatum. Cardiomegaly is not a sensitive indicator of left ventricular
systolic dysfunction and cardiomegaly on chest X-ray has normal echocardiograms. Dilatation of
individual cardiac chambers can be recognised by the characteristic alterations to the cardiac
silhouette in X-ray ? Left atrial dilatation results in prominence of the left atrial appendage, appears
as straight left heart border, a double cardiac shadow to the right of the sternum, and widening of the
angle of the carina (bifurcation of the trachea) as the left main bronchus is pushed upwards. ? Right
atrial enlargement projects from the right heart border towards the right lower lung field. ? Left
ventricular dilatation causes prominence of the left heart border and cardiomegaly. Left ventricular
hypertrophy produces rounding of the left heart border. ? Right ventricular dilatation increases heart
size, displaces the apex upwards and straightens the left heart border. ? Lateral or oblique film may
detect pericardial calcification in patients with constrictive pericarditis or a calcified thoracic aortic
aneurysm. which may be obscured by the spine on the PA view. ? The lung fields shows congestion
and oedema in patients with heart failure, and an increase in pulmonary blood flow (pulmonary
plethora') in those with left-to-right shunt. Pleural effusions may also occur in heart failure.

Doesn't prevent progression of airway remodelling or the more rapid decline in lung function that occur in asthma. any severity and age. Drugs are:-

It may reduce exacerbations in patients not controlled on maximal inhaler therapy.

Which of the following drugs are implicated in peptic ulcer disease, not caused by Helicobacter pylori and NSAIDs? 
1. Clopidogrel 
2. Glucocorticoids 
3. Bisphosphonates
 4. Colloidal bismuth subcitrate 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1. Clopidogrel -Correct • Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that
inhibits ADP receptors on platelets. • It can impair mucosal healing and has been associated with
increased gastric and duodenal ulcers, especially when used with other drugs like aspirin. •
Clopidogrel can cause PUD independently, even in the absence of H. pylori or NSAID use. 2.
Glucocorticoids – Correct • On their own, glucocorticoids have modest ulcerogenic potential, but this
increases significantly when used with NSAIDs. • They reduce gastric mucus production, impair
prostaglandin synthesis, and delay mucosal healing, contributing to ulcer risk. 3. Bisphosphonates –
Correct • Drugs like alendronate or risedronate are known to cause upper GI irritation. • They can
lead to esophagitis, gastritis, and in some cases, peptic ulcers due to direct mucosal damage,
especially when not taken properly (e.g., without water or lying down). 4. Colloidal bismuth subcitrate
– Incorrect • This is actually used in the treatment of PUD, particularly in H. pylori eradication
regimens. • It has protective and antimicrobial properties and helps coat the gastric mucosa. • Not
ulcerogenic — in fact, it helps in ulcer healing.

Vertical transmission of hepatitis B can be prevented by which of the following interventions? 
1. Passive immunisation of infant at birth 
2. Active immunisation of infant at birth 
3. Antiviral therapy in third trimester for mother with HBV-DNA level of> 2, 00,000 IU/mL 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Prevention of transmission of Hepatitis virus
Hepatitis B:- For unvaccinated persons post-exposure prophylaxis with a combination of HBIG, and
hepatitis B vaccine is recommended. Both HBIG and hepatitis B vaccine can be given at same time
but separate site. For perinatal exposure of infants born to HbsAg-positive mothers- passive
immunisation by a single dose of HBIG, 0.5 mL, IM in the thigh immediately after birth, followed by
active immunisation with three doses of hepatitis B vaccines started within the first 12 h of life. For
pregnant mothers with high-level HBV DNA (>2 x 10' 1U/mL), nucleoside analogues (tenofovir) during
the third trimester of pregnancy reduces further perinatal transmission. For accidental exposure (e.g.,
accidental needle stick, other mucosal penetration, or ingestion), a single IM dose of HBIG, 0.06
mL/kg, as soon as possible, followed by a complete course of vaccine to given within the first week
Currently, booster does not recommended routinely, except in immunosuppressed persons who have
lost detectable anti-HBs or immunocompetent persons who sustain percutaneous HbsAg-positive
inoculations after losing detectable antibody. Hepatitis C:- IG is ineffective in preventing hepatitis C
12
and is no longer recommended for post exposure prophylaxis in cases of perinatal, needle stick, or
sexual exposure. For stable, monogamous sexual partners, sexual transmission of hepatitis C is
unlikely, and sexual barrier precautions are not recommended. For persons with multiple sexual
partners or with STD, the risk is increased, and barrier precautions are recommended. No special
precautions are recommended for babies born to mothers with hepatitis C, and breast-feeding does
not have to be restricted. Hepatitis E: - For prevention of hepatitis E, IG derived from HEV endemic
populations does not appear to be effective. Hepatitis A: - Both passive immunization with
immunoglobulin (IG) and active immunization with killed vaccines are available. For postexposure
prophylaxis of intimate contacts (household, sexual, institutional) administration of 0.02 ml/kg is
recommended as early after exposure as possible but may effective even after 2 weeks. Prophylaxis
not necessary for those who already received vaccine, for casual contacts (office, factory, school, or
hospital), for most elderly persons (likely to be immune), for those known to have anti-HAV in their
serum. Currently, hepatitis A vaccine (not IG) is recommended for all persons aged ?12 months for
postexposure prophylaxis and for preexposure prophylaxis prior to international travel to HAVendemic
areas.

Which of the following are correct in respect of jaundice? 
1. Patients complain of darkening of urine before they notice jaundice 
2. Jaundice is usually detectable with a serum bilirubin level of over 1-8 mg/dl 
3. In Gilbert syndrome, jaundice is more noticeable after fasting 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 1 and 3 only Explanation: Some important point regarding jaundice
Jaundice is the hallmark symptom of liver disease and perhaps the most reliable marker of severity.
Sclerae have high affinity for bilirubin due to elastin content, and the presence of scleral icterus
indicates a serum bilirubin at least 51 umol/L. (3 mg/dl). It is rarely detectable if bilirubin level <43>342 μmol/L (>20 mg)
d.)] and neurologic impairment due to kernicterus leading to death Gilbert's syndrome has mild
unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with serum levels almost always <103 mol/L (6 mg/dL) and
jaundice is often identified only during periods of stress, concurrent illness, alcohol use, or fasting.

Which of the following are correct regarding Essential Tremors? 
1. It may present at any age 
2. Head is almost never involved 
3. Tremor may improve with small amount of alcohol 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 1 and 3 only Explanation: Some important point regarding essential tremor: ? ET is the most common movement disorder; can present in childhood but dramatically
increases in after>70 years. High-frequency tremor (6-10 Hz) mainly affects the upper extremities.
Most often manifest as a postural or action tremor and, in severe cases, can interfere eating and
drinking. Bilateral and symmetric but may begin on one side and remain asymmetric. Severe cases
have an intention tremor with overshoot and slowness of movement suggesting the possibility of a
cerebellar origin. ? Etiology unknown. 50% have positive family history with an AD pattern of
inheritance. It involves head (30%), voice (20%), tongue (20%), face/ jaw (10%), lower limbs (10%)
and multiple body part (50%). ? It characteristically improved by alcohol and worsened by stress.
Usually other neurologic examination is normal but subtle impairment of coordination or tandem
walking, disturbances of hearing, cognition, personality, mood, and olfaction. ? Parkinsonism can be
differentiated from ET because the former stops at the onset of a voluntary action and is typically
associated with bradykinesia with progressive slowing of sequential movements, rigidity, gait and
postural instability, and other parkinsonian features. ? T/t-Mild case- no treatment only reassurance.
Beta blockers and primidone are the standard treatment. Hand tremor usually improves, while head
tremor is often refractory.

Which of the following are the tests for functional assessment of encephalopathy ? 
1. Flapping tremors 
2. Number connection test 
3. Constructional apraxia 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Some important point regarding hepatic
encephalopathy:- Assessment of encephalopathy: (i) Flapping tremor or asterixis (Jerky forward
movements every 5-10 s, when arms are outstretched and hands are dorsiflexed; the movements are
coarser than those seen in tremor), (ii) number connection test (inability to perform simple mental
arithmetic tasks), (iii) constructional apraxia (inability to draw objects such as a star). Clinical
feature:-It occurs in 30%-40% of patients with cirrhosis. Symptoms are inability to concentrate,
delirium, disorientation, drowsiness, slurring of speech and eventually coma develop. Seizures are
rare. Other features are hyper-reflexia and bilateral extensor plantar responses. Rarely causes focal
neurological signs; if present, other causes must be sought. Fetor hepaticus, a sweet musty odour to
the breath, is usually present but is more a sign of liver failure and portosystemic shunting.
Cerebellar dysfunction, Parkinsonian syndromes, spastic paraplegia and dementia are rare.
Management-Remove precipitating causes and to suppress the production of neurotoxins by bacteria
in the bowel. Lactulose given until the bowels are moving twice daily that limits colonic ammonia
absorption, and promotes the incorporation of nitrogen into bacteria. Phosphate enemas, rifaximin,
amino acid combination L-ornithine L-arginine (LOLA) in lowering ammonia levels; protein restriction
is no longer recommended Factors precipitating encephalopathy:- Drugs (especially sedatives,
antidepressants), dehydration (including diuretics, paracentesis), portosystemic shunting, infection,
hypokalaemia, hyponatraemia, constipation, Protein load (including gastrointestinal bleeding)
Differential diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy- Intracranial bleed (subdural/extradural
haematoma), drug or alcohol intoxication, delirium tremens/alcohol withdrawal, Wernicke's
encephalopathy, primary psychiatric disorders, hypoglycaemia, neurological Wilson's disease, postictal
state.

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct regarding blood components in clinical practice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Transfusion associated GVHD can be prevented by prior irradiation of transfused blood
Explanation: Some important point regarding blood components (BC), its transfusion, complications
and management.
ABO blood group antigens are oligosaccharide chains that project from the red cell surface which
attached to proteins and lipids of red cell membrane.
If RhD-positive red cells enter the circulation of an RhD-negative mother, IgG antibodies are
produced. It crosses placenta and cause hemolysis and severe neurological damage or death due to
haemolytic disease of the newborn. For prevention RhD-negative women should be given anti-D
perinatally.
Most frequent causes of death were transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) (32%),
followed by TRALI (26%), hemolysis (18%), and sepsis (14%).
Malaria is less severe in type O than non-O patients. Blood group O is susceptible to Helicobacter
pylori.
RBC Ag may be the target of autoantibodies generating autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Some of
them, mostly IgG, are active at 37°C, called "warm autoantibodies," and are most often directed
against Rh Ag, while others, most often IgM, are active at 4°C, called "cold autoantibodies," and may
be directed against ABO, I. I. P, and other Ag
43 RBC group systems described, five (Rh, Kell, Duffy, Kidd, and MNS) are routinely investigated
with transfusion compatibility of 95% Platelets stored At 20-24°C and under permanent motion for
3-7 days (5 day Davidson) or At 4°C without motion: up to 14-21 days, If irradiated: <24>90% of cases. Prevention - Gamma or X-ray irradiation of cellular BC
or treating BC with pathogen reduction. At-risk patients are: inherited immune deficiency, Hodgkin
lymphoma, patients with aplastic anaemia receiving immunosuppressive therapy with antithymocyte
globulin, patients undergoing autologous or allogeneic hematopoietic transplantation, those taking
T-lymphocyte-suppressing drugs, such as fludarabine and other purine or pyrimidine analogues, anti-
CD52 Ab or antithymocyte globulin, fetuses receiving intrauterine transfusions, and recipients of BC
given by blood relative. Granulocyte concentrates contain a large number of lymphocytes, so always
be irradiated.
TACO:-Risk factors are older age, renal failure, preexisting fluid overload, cardiac dysfunction,
administration of a large volume of BCs, and an excessive rate of transfusion comparative to
hemodynamic tolerance. C/F- Dyspnea, hypoxia, bilateral and predominantly alveolar infiltrates on
chest x-ray, frequent systolic hypertension, and elevated brain natriuretic peptide, Fever may also
exist. Prevention - identifying at-risk patients, close monitoring, a slow transfusion rate and use of
diuretics in hemodynamically stable patients. Treatment requires stopping the transfusion and
administrating oxygen and diuretics.
18
Electrolyte imbalance- Transfusion total blood volume over 3 h or >5-10 units of RBCCs cause citrate
toxicity, hypothermia and cardiac dysrhythmias, (due to BC at 4°C), hyperkalemia, and dilutional
coagulopathy, Citrate chelates calcium causing hypocalcemia, manifested by circumoral paresthesia,
and changes in cardiac function
Iron overload. Each unit of RBCs contains 200-250 mg of iron, its accumulation affect endocrine,
hepatic, and cardiac function. Acute hypotensive transfusion reactions defined as an abrupt drop in
blood pressure of >30 mmHg carly after the start of transfusion and resolving quickly once the
transfusion is stopped, without further intervention.

Which of the following are correct with regard to metformin? 
1. The maximum tolerated dose is 2000 mg/day

Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 1, 2 and 3 Antidiabetic drug used for type II DM, its use, mechanism of action and adverse effect



Some newer agents clearly protect against cardiovascular disease (GLP-1 receptor agonists and SGLT2 inhibitors), but are more expensive. Others (metformin and thiazolidinediones) provide some cardiovascular protection, but are cheaper, while others do not (sulphonylureas, DPP-4 inhibitors and insulin). SGLT2 inhibitors have additional protective properties in heart failure and diabetic kidney disease, while TZDs (thiazolidinediones) increase rates of heart failure. Approaches to drug therapy in type 2 DM:- Improve insulin availability- Exogenous insulin, Sulfonylureas, Meglitinide/phenylalanine analogues, Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (DPP 4is), and GLP-1 receptor agonists Overcome insulin resistance- Biguanides (Metformin), Thiazolidinediones (Pioglitazone), a-glucosidase inhibitors

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding short stature? 
1. Linear bone growth rates are pituitary dependent 
2. Normal bone age in a child with short stature suggests hormonal disorder 
3. Final height in boys can be estimated by adding 6-5 cm to mid-parental height 
4. Replacement therapy with recombinant GH restores growth velocity in GH-deficient children 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 1, 3 and 4 Explanation: Some important points regarding skeletal
maturation and somatic growth The growth plate is dependent on a variety of hormonal stimuli,
including GH, insulin like growth factor (IGF)-1, sex steroids, thyroid hormones, paracrine and
circulating growth factors (e.g., fibroblast growth factor family), and cytokines. Linear bone growth
rates are very high in infancy and are pituitary dependent. Mean growth velocity is around 6 cm/year
in later childhood. Peak growth rates occur during midpuberty when bone age is 12 (girls) or 13
(boys). In general, delayed bone age in a child with short stature is suggestive of a hormonal or
systemic disorder, whereas normal bone age in a short child is more likely to be caused by a genetic
cartilage dysplasia or growth plate disorder. Caloric deprivation, malnutrition, uncontrolled diabetes,
and chronic renal failure are secondary causes of abrogated GH receptor function and short stature
with normal or elevated GH and low IGF-1 levels. Psychological and social deprivation causes growth
retardation, delayed speech, discordant hyperphagia, and an attenuated response to GH
administration. A nurturing environment restores growth rates. Diagnosis- Short stature should be
evaluated if a patient's height is below >3 SD or decelerated growth rate. Skeletal maturation is best
evaluated by radiologic bone age, based on the degree of wrist bone growth plate fusion. Final height
predicted by using standardized scales (Bayley-Pinneau or Tanner-Whitehouse) or estimated by
adding 6.5 cm (boys) or subtracting 6.5 cm (girls) from the midparental height. Lab Investigation:-
Since GH secretion is pulsatile, GH deficiency is assessed by the response to provocative stimuli, i.e.
exercise, insulin-induced hypoglycemia, and other pharmacologic tests that normally increase GH to
>7 μg/L in children. Random GH measurements do not distinguish normal children from GH
deficiency. Treatment:- Replacement therapy with recombinant GH (0.02-0.05 mg/kg per day SC)
restores growth velocity around 10 cm/year. GH treatment is moderately effective in Turner
syndrome and chronic renal failure. GH treatment for psychosocial or constitutional (idiopathic) short
stature is not recommended. In GH insensitivity and growth retardation due to mutations of the GH
21
receptor, treatment with IGF-1 bypasses the dysfunctional GH receptor.

A 15 year girl presents to the hospital with severe abdominal pain, vomiting and cold extremities.
She has tachycardia and hypotension. Lab investigations show blood glucose 400 mg/dl, blood pH
6-9, urine ketones +++ and serum creatinine of 1-4 mg/dL. She is promptly administered IV fluids
and insulin. After 4 hours, she complains of inability to lift her limbs. What is the next step to be
considered in her management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Potassium repletion. The patient's presentation with severe abdominal
pain, vomiting, and metabolic acidosis, coupled with hyperglycemia and ketonuria, is characteristic of
Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA). The initial management with IV fluids and insulin is appropriate.
However, the subsequent development of "inability to lift her limbs" is a critical sign of severe
hypokalemia. During DKA, the body has a total potassium deficit, but acidosis initially shifts
potassium out of cells, often masking true depletion. When insulin is administered, it drives both
glucose and potassium back into the cells, leading to a rapid and significant drop in serum potassium
levels. Severe hypokalemia can cause life-threatening muscle weakness, paralysis (including
respiratory muscles), and cardiac arrhythmias, making immediate potassium repletion vital for
patient safety.

questions.text: In a healthy young adult, what proportion of sleep time is comprised Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 20-25% Explanation: Some important point regarding sleep pattern:- ?
The stages of human sleep are defined on the basis of characteristic patterns in the EEG,
electrooculogram (EOG) and EMG measured on the chin, neck, and legs. Continuous recording all
three called polysomnography. ? NREM sleep is subdivided into three stages: N1, N2, and N3,
characterized by an increasing threshold for arousal and slowing of the cortical EEG. NREM stages N1
and N2 constitute 50-60% while N3 sleep (slow-wave sleep) predominates in the first third of the
night and comprise 15-25% total sleep time in young adults. Age has a profound impact on sleep. N3
sleep is most prominent in childhood, decreasing in puberty and 2nd and 3 decades and may be
absent in older. ? REM sleep is characterized by low-amplitude, mixed-frequency EEG, similar to
NREM stage N1, and an EOG pattern of REMS. EMG activity is absent in nearly all skeletal muscles
except those involved in respiration, characteristic of REM sleep. REM sleep constitutes 20-25% of
total sleep in adult, while 50% in infancy. ? The first REM sleep episode usually occurs in the 24 hour
of sleep. NREM and REM sleep alternate with an average period of 90-110 min (ultradian sleep cycle).
After sleep deprivation, NREM sleep recovers first, followed by REM sleep. Prolactin secretion is
pulsatile, with the highest secretory peaks occurring during NREM sleep. Nocturnal erections occur
during REM ? Inadequate sleep is associated with glucose intolerance that may lead to diabetes,
obesity, and metabolic syndrome, impaired immune responses, accelerated atherosclerosis,
increased risk of cardiac disease, cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease, and stroke.

Hormonal regulation of salt and water balance in a nephron occurs at:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Collecting Ducts Explanation: Hormone regulation occurs in both DCT
and collecting duct. And option "c" and "d" both are correct but I will like to go with option "d" which
seems to be more correct. Now it's upon you to select correct answer. Aldosterone secreted by the
zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex enhances sodium reabsorption (and potassium excretion) by
the collecting tubule and favor edema formation. ? Angiotensin II has generalized vasoconstrictor
properties, particularly on the renal efferent arterioles. It enhances salt and water reabsorption in the
proximal tubule as well as in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle. All that enters the systemic
circulation stimulates the production of aldosterone. Blockade of the action of aldosterone by
spironolactone or eplerenone (aldosterone antagonists) or by amiloride (a blocker of epithelial
sodium channels) often induces a moderate diuresis in edematous states. ? Secretion of arginine
vasopressin (AVP) by the posterior pituitary gland occurs in response to increased intracellular
osmolar concentration; and increases the reabsorption of free water in the distal tubules and
collecting ducts.

Which component of auto-regulation of glomerular filtration acts on the efferent arteriole ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Angiotensin II mediated vasoconstriction Explanation: Glomerulus is
impermeable to proteins the size of albumin > 67kDa, while proteins of <20 kDa or smaller are
filtered freely. Filtration pressure in glomerulus is normally maintained at a constant level even in
variations in systemic blood pressure and cardiac output, by alterations in muscle tone within the
afferent and efferent arterioles and mesangial cells; known as autoregulation. Due to decrease
perfusion pressure, local production of prostaglandins increases that cause vasodilatation of the
afferent arteriole increasing the intraglomerular pressure. Apart of it renin (cleaves angiotensinogen
angiotensin I, which is cleaved by ACE to angiotensin II) is released by smooth muscle cells in the
juxtaglomerular apparatus in response to reduced perfusion pressure, stimulation of sympathetic
nerves or low sodium of fluid in the distal convoluted tubule at the macula densa. Angiotensin II
restores glomerular perfusion pressure causing vasoconstriction of the efferent arterioles to raise
intraglomerular pressure selectively, and inducing systemic vasoconstriction to increase blood
pressure and thus renal perfusion pressure.

questions.text: Sickle cell syndromes are caused by a mutation in the B-globin gene. Which one of the following correctly describes the change?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Sixth amino acid-glutamic acid is replaced by valine. Explanation: Some
important point regarding sickle cell disease:- ? Sickle-cell disease results from a single substitution
of glutamic acid to valine at position 6 of the beta globin polypeptide chain; AR inheritance.
Homozygotes only produce abnormal beta chains (HbS, termed SS), and this results in the clinical
syndrome of sickle-cell disease. Heterozygotes (HbA and HbS) results in sickle-cell trait and it may be
associated with an increased risk of sudden and cardiovascular death in young adults. ? Common in
African American populations; Sickle-cell trait are relatively resistant to the effects of falciparum
malaria in early childhood ? Clinical features: Background retinopathy, proliferative retinopathy,
vitreous bleeds, sickle chest syndrome, infection, pulmonary hypertension, osteomyelitis, hepatic
sequestration, cholelithiasis, enuresis, haematuria, papillary necrosis, chronic renal failure, dactylitis,
arthropathy, subarachnoid bleed, fits, cerebrovascular event, sickle myocardium, cardiomegaly,
transfusional iron overload, splenic infarction, vertebral collapse, osteoporosis, avascular necrosis,
priapism, leg ulceration, ? Definitive diagnosis done by haemoglobin electrophoresis to demonstrate
the absence of HbA, 2%-20% Hbf and the predominance of HbS.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct about treatment with vit D supplement? 
1. Serum calcium levels improve earlier than serum PTH levels. 
2. Patients should be closely observed with serial vitamin D levels in blood as vitamin D toxicity occurs frequently 
3. Vitamin D supplementation should always be in conjunction with calcium supplementation 
4. Nephrolithiasis is a known complication 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 1, 3 and 4 Explanation: Some important point regarding Vitamin D
deficiency and treatment:- The most specific screening test for vitamin D deficiency is a serum
25(OH)D level. 25(OH) D level <37>50 nmol/L (>20 ng/mL). Vitamin D deficiency ? impaired intestinal absorption of calcium
decreased serum total and ionized calcium values ? hypocalcemia ? secondary hyperparathyroidism,
? PTH-induced increase in bone turnover (phosphaturia, hypophosphatemia) ? ?alkaline phosphatase.
1, 25(OH)2D level are not accurate reflections of vitamin D stores and not used to diagnose vitamin D
deficiency in patients with normal renal function. Recommended daily intake of vitamin D is 600 IU
from 1 to 70 years of age, and 800 IU for those >70. Safety margin for vitamin D is large, and vitamin
D toxicity observed only when taken 40,000 IU daily. Vitamin D should always be repleted in
conjunction with calcium supplementation. The hepatic enzyme cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4) is a
strong inducer of the catabolism of vitamin D metabolites. Phenytoin and rifampicin, lead to strong
induction and need higher dose. Level of calcium becomes normal within 1 week of therapy, while
increases in PTH and ALP may persist for 3-6 months. Most efficacious methods to monitor treatment
and resolution of vitamin D deficiency are measurement of serum and urinary calcium. Those taking
vitamin D and calcium the 24-h urinary calcium excretion should be 100-250 mg/24 h. Levels >250
mg/24 h may lead to nephrolithiasis

questions.text: The first line investigation for diagnostic evaluation of patients with hypercalcemia is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Serum i PTH levels Explanation: The first step in the diagnostic
evaluation of hyper- or hypocalcemia is to ensure that serum albumin should be normal. 50% of total
calcium is ionized, and the rest is bound to albumin. MC cause of chronic hypercalcemia is primary
hyperparathyroidism. Once true hypercalcemia is established, the second most important laboratory
test in the diagnostic evaluation is a PTH level. Increases in PTH are often accompanied by
hypophosphatemia. ? PTH, fcalcium and phosphorus, diagnosis is almost always primary
hyperparathyroidism. Patients with Familial hypercalciuric hypercalciuria can have similar
biochemical picture to primary hyperparathyroidism but typically low urinary calcium excretion.

A patient receiving chemotherapy develops neutropenia. He presents with fever, cough, expectoration, chest pain and hemoptysis. His CT scan of chest reveals nodular infiltrates with halo sign and crescent sign. The most useful drug for treating him is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Voriconazole Explanation: This is a case of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis Is most commonly a complication of severe neutropenia caused by drugs (especially immunosuppressive agents) or disease. Risk factors are:- Neutropenia:, solid organ or allogeneic stem cell transplantation, prolonged highdose glucocorticoid therapy, leukaemia and other haematological malignancies, cytotoxic chemotherapy, advanced HIV disease, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, critically ill patients on intensive care units, chronic granulomatous disease. Culture or histopathological evidence of Aspergillus in diseased tissues provides a definitive diagnosis





Treatment: The drug of choice is voriconazole. Second-line drugs are liposomal amphotericin, caspofungin, posaconazole and isavuconazole. Response may be assessed by estimation of the circulating galactomannan level. Posaconazole (200 mg 3 times daily) or itraconazole (200 mg/day) may be prescribed for primary prophylaxis

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding post gonococcal urethritis (PGU) is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) PGU refers to non-gonococcal urethritis in men treated earlier with
single dose of penicillin Explanation: Post Gonococcal urethritis:- C. trachomatis is the most common
cause of nongonococcal urethritis and postgonococcal urethritis. Postgonococcal urethritis can be
defined as nongonococcal urethritis developing in men 2-3 weeks after treatment of gonococcal
urethritis with single doses of agents such as penicillin or cephalosporins, which lack antimicrobial
activity against chlamydiae. Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin; is effective
against concomitant chlamydial infection. Other causes of nongonococcal urethritis are Mycoplasma
genitalium, Trichomonas vaginalis, and herpes simplex virus. C. trachomatis urethritis is generally
less severe than gonococcal urethritis.

Which of the following are used in the treatment of Acne vulgaris? 
1. Topical benzoyl peroxide 
2. Topical antibiotics like clindamycin 
3. Oral isotretinoin 
4. Oral ivermectin 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Acne vulgaris:- ? Chronic inflammation of the
pilosebaceous units, extremely common, generally starts during puberty and has been estimated to
affect over 90% of adolescents (12-20 year); severe in later adolescence, can persist into the thirties
and forties, especially in females. Increased sebum production; colonisation of pilosebaceous ducts
by Propionibacterium acnes and occlusion of gland ? Both androgens and progestogens increase
sebum excretion and oestrogens reduce; may have positive family history ? Usually affects the face
(earliest in forhead) and often the trunk; hallmark is open comedones (blackheads) are dilated
keratin filled follicles, which appear as black papules due to the keratin debris and closed comedones
(whiteheads) usually have no visible follicular opening and are caused by accumulation of sebum and
keratin deeper in the pilosebaceous ducts. Scarring may follow Acne conglobata: characterised by
comedones, nodules, abscesses, sinuses and cysts, usually with marked scarring. Rare, usually
affecting adult males and MC on trunk and upper limbs; may associated with hidradenitis
suppurativa. Acne fulminans: Rare but severe; associated with fever, arthralgias and systemic
inflammation, with raised neutrophil count and plasma viscosity. usually found on the trunk in
adolescent males. Costochondritis can occur. Acne excoriée: self-inflicted excoriations due to
compulsive picking of pre-existing or imagined acne lesions. It usually affects adolescent girls, and
underlying psychological problems are common. Treatment: ? Mild to moderate disease:- Topical
therapy- Benzoyl peroxide or retinoids, azelaic acid. For inflammatory acne- antibiotics (erythromycin
or clindamycin), in moderated disease- systemic tetracycline, lymecycline if fails than erythromycin
or trimethoprim. In women oestrogen- containing OCP can be a useful adjunct, estrogen + antiandrogen
(Cyproterone acetate) is also option. ? Isotretinoin has revolutionised the treatment of
moderate to severe acne. Combination with systemic glucocorticoid may be required in the short
term to reduce flare early in the treatment. Depression and suicide have been reported in association
with isotretinoin. Intralesional triamcinolone may be sued. CO, laser, microdermabrasion, chemical
peeling or localised excision done for scarring. UV B phototherapy or PDT can occasionally be used
Acne Rosacea ? Chronic inflammatory condition affects the central face and consists of flushing,
erythema, papules, pustules and telangiectasiae. Cause unknown; normal sebum excretion, no
comedones. Most commonly affects fair-skinned female but severe in male. Seen almost exclusively
in adults, only rarely affecting patients <30 years. It can be exacerbated by heat, sunlight and
alcohol emotional stimuli, hot drinks, or spicy foods. Very long standing may lead to connective tissue
overgrowth, particularly of the nose (rhinophyma) ? Mild disease may respond to topical
antimicrobials, such as metronidazole or azelaic acid. Topical ivermectin may be beneficial in some
cases. Tetracycline or erythromycin.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an indication for self-injectable adrenaline (epinephrine)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Anaphylaxis to allergens that is difficult to avoid Explanation: Some
important point regarding self-injectable adrenaline (epinephrine) Indications:- ? Anaphylaxis to
allergens that are difficult to avoid (insect venom, foods), idiopathic anaphylactic reactions ? History
of severe localised reactions with high risk of future anaphylaxis (reaction to trace allergen likely
repeated exposure to allergen. ? History of severe localised reactions with high risk of adverse
outcome( poorly controlled asthma, lack of access to emergency care ? Caution with B-blockers in
anaphylactic patients as they may increase the severity of an anaphylactic reaction and reduce the
response to adrenaline. ? Measurement of serum mast cell tryptase concentrations is useful to
confirm the diagnosis

questions.text:
Which of the following statements with regard to arterio-venous fistula in dialysis patient are
correct? 
1. Distension and thickening of vessel wall occurs 
2. Formed upto a year before dialysis is contemplated 
3. Leg veins are usually preferred 
4. Synthetic graft may be used if fistula formation is not possible 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 1, 2 and 4 Explanation: ? Vascular access for haemodialysis done by
formation of an AV fistula, usually in the forearm (75%) [Side-to-side-anastomoses of radial artery
with cephalic vein at the wrist Le. Cimino fistula], up to a year before dialysis is contemplated. After
4-6 weeks, pressure transmitted from the artery to the vein leading from the fistula causes distension
and thickening of the vessel wall (arterialisation). If creation of an AVF is not possible, synthetic
polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) grafts may be done between an artery and a vein. ? Patients must be
screened for hepatitis B, hepatitis C and HIV, and vaccinated against hepatitis B if they are not
immune. Patients with hepatitis C and HIV are less infectious and can be treated satisfactorily using
machine segregation and standard infection control measures. Haemodialysis is usually done for 3-5
hours three times weekly. ? Hemodialysis Catheters are made of polyurethane that softens at body
temperature but is sufficiently strong to allow for blood flow rates of 400-500 mL/min in each of two
channels inside a 14.5-16 F design without collapse of catheter. Catheter-related bacteremia is best
treated with exchange of the catheter. >3 months catheter wall contact points lead to central vein
stenosis.

questions.text: An infant was born at 30 weeks of gestation and weighs 1-2 kg at birth. Which of the following is the recommended initial feeding method?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Orogastric feeding Explanation: Methods of feeding


Term neonates lose 1-3% birth wt/d with cumulative loss 5-10% in the first week. Preterm neonates lose 2-3% birth wt/d with cumulative loss 10-15% in first week. Failure of wt loss in first week is indicative of excessive fluid administration. Excessive (>3%) loss/day in 5-7 days is non physiological. Robust sucking pattern is not present until 32- 34 weeks gestation. Coordination between sucking, swallowing and breathing does not mature till 34 weeks and fully matures by 37 to 38 weeks of gestation. Expressed breast milk should start within hour so that infant gets colostrum. Expressed 43 milk can be stored for about 6 hours at room temperature and for 24 hours in domestic refrigerator (2° to 8°C). Enteral feeding is important for sick neonates. Sepsis is not contraindication of enteral feeding unless associated with shock, sclerema, NEC. Infants who are fed by spoon/paladai or by intragastric tube:- VLBW infants (<1500>1500 g) are given 60 mL/kg fluids on the first day and increased by about 15-20 mL/kg/ day to a maximum of 160 ml/kg/ day by the end of the first week. Birth weight of 1500-2499 g (34 weeks) need additional vitamin D and iron supplement. A well-hydrated baby should pass urine at 1 to 3 ml/kg/hr. Growth monitoring of LBW infant:-Both term and preterm LBW infants lose weight (about 10% and 15%, respectively) in the first 7 days of life; they regain their birth weight by 10-14 days. After that wt gain should be at least 15-20 g/kg/day till a weight reach upto 2-2.5 kg. After that weight gain of 20 to 40 g/ day is considered appropriate.

Which of the following are age appropriate language milestones in a normally developing 2 year old child?

4. Stating his name when asked 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:

Which of the following tools are used for developmental screening? 
1. Denver-II 
2. Ages and Stages Questionnaire 
3. Parents Evaluation of Developmental Status 
4. Bayley Scale for Infant and Toddler Development 
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 1, 2 and 3 Explanation: Parents' Evaluations of Development Status
(PEDS) and Ages and Stages Questionnaires (ASQ) are popular screening tools in west. In India
popular tools are:- Phatak's Baroda screening test: India's best testing system developed by
Dr.Promila Phatak; used by child psychologists rather than physicians;is Indian adaptation of Bayley
development scale. Applied to children up to 30 months. Ages and stages questionnaire (ASQ-3): It
consists of age- based, parent-completed questionnaires. Used from one month to 5 years of age. It
assesses communication, gross motor, fine motor, problem solving, and personal-social. Denver II or
revised DDST assesses gross motor, fine motor adaptive, language and personal-social behaviour.
Trivandrum development screening chart: consists of 51 items for children of 0-6 years. Clinical
adaptive test and clinical linguistic and auditory milestone scale (CAT/CLAMS): used to assess the
child's cognitive and language skills and uses parental report and direct testing of the child's skills.
Used at ages of 0-36 months. Goodenough-Harris drawing test: Simple nonverbal intelligence test
requires only a pencil or pen and white unlined paper. Bayley scale for infant development II is
definitive test not screening used for 1 months to 3.5 years. Other definitive test are Wechsler
intelligence scale for children IV (age 6 to 17 years), Stanford-Binet intelligence scales, 5th edition
(age 2 to 85 years), Vineland adaptive behavior scale II (age 0 to 89 years)

questions.text:
According to King's College criteria, which of the following are the indicators for referring to liver transplantation following acetaminophen toxicity? 
1. Transaminase levels> 4000 IU/L 
2. Acdemia (Serum pH <7>6) 
4. Renal dysfunction (creatinine > 3-4 mg/dL)
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 2, 3 and 4 Explanation: King's College criteria used for acetaminophen
toxicity to decide referral for liver transplantation. These are (a) acidemia (serum pH <73>6), (c) renal dysfunction (creatinine >3.4 mg/dl),
(d) grade III or IV hepatic encephalopathy. Transaminase elevation is not involved in determining liver
transplantation. The initial management of paracetamol overdose is gastric lavage within 4 hours of
ingestion and therapy with its antidote, N-acetylcysteine (oral or IV) which is precursor for glutathione
synthesis and it reduces hepatotoxicity. Single acetaminophen blood level obtained at least 4 hours
of ingestion and plotted on the Rumack-Matthew nomogram to decide treatment. Normal therapeutic
level is 10-20 mg/ml. Nomogram predicts the risk of hepatotoxicity at a single point in time, and
cannot predict hepatic failure during the illness or patient death; cannot used for multiple doses of
paracetamol or 24 hours after of ingestion, not useful for associated opioid or anticholinergic agents
ingestion.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Gastric lavage Explanation: Acetaminophen toxicity is the MC cause of

questions.text: Antidote to reverse the muscarinic effects of organophosphate toxicity is

A 7 year old child is brought to the emergency with seizures and drowsiness. The child had been
receiving some drugs for fever for the past two days. Child is found to be cyanosed with an oxygen
saturation of 40% and unresponsive to oxygen therapy. Blood gas analysis reveals a normal PaO2.
Which drug intake may have caused the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Chloroquine
Explanation: This is a case of Chloroquine toxicity taken for malarial fever and the child developed
methemoglobinemia. Some important point regarding chloroquine toxicity:
Chloroquine is well absorbed orally has a large volume of distribution; accumulates especially
in heart, kidney, liver, pancreas, lung and spleen, and is strongly bound in melanin-containing
cells (eye and skin). Renal excretion enhanced by acidification of the urine.
C/F :- Malaise, anorexia, pruritus, urticaria, haemolytic anaemia, methaemoglobinaemia,
retinopathy, psychosis, seizures, convulsions, vertigo, headache. Sudden apnoea can occur.
CVS manifestations comprise hypotension, atrioventricular conduction defects, and cardiac
arrhythmias. Hypokalemia is often present. Effects of chloroquine retinopathy rare pigmentary
stippling, mottling, a "bull's eye" pattern of macular hyperpigmentation, attenuation of the
retinal arteries, pale optic discs, disturbance of colour vision, loss of central vision scotoma and
visual field defects.
Features of methemoglobinemia may be asymptomatic or lethargy, stupor, seizure. Acute
methemoglobinemia is life threatening when MetHb >50% of total circulatory haemoglobin.
ABG reveals normal PaO, and low SpO, Filter paper test shows blood is chocolate coloured not
changing after exposure to oxygen. Treatment is methylene blue. Patients with G6PD
deficiency should not receive methylene blue. Other t/t are ascorbic acid, hyperbaric oxygen
and exchange transfusion.
Indications of severe toxicity: (i) systolic BP < 90>110 ms, (ii)
hypokalaemia (K+<3.0 mEq).
Cardiovascular effects include hypotension, vasodilation, ECG abnormalities (prolonged PR,
QRS, and QT interval), ventricular arrhythmias and cardiovascular collapse.
Fatal dose: As little as 2.25 to 3 grams in an adult. About 2 to 3 times the therapeutic dose
may be fatal in children.

questions.text: Which vaccines are stored in the top rack of the main refrigerator compartment at temperature of 4-10°C?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) BCG, Measles and MMR vaccines Explanation: Vaccine placed in the refrigerator with freezer on top is as follows: Measles, BCG, rota virus vaccine and OPV on the top shelf. DPT, pentavalent vaccine, TT, IPV, hepatitis B, and JE vaccine on the middle shelf and diluents next to vaccine with which they are supplied Ice-packs filled with water on the bottom shelf and in the door of the refrigerator. Vaccine placed in the ice lined refrigerator (ILR):- All the vaccines should be kept in the basket provided with the ILR. ILR cabinet temperature is between +2°C to + 8°C and are used to store vaccines at district and sub-district level. It is top opening refrigerators. In case basket is not available, two layers of empty ice-packs can be laid flat on the bottom of the ILR. DPT, TT, hep B, IPV and pentavalent vaccines and diluents are kept in upper part of the basket. Upper part is preferred location for storing the freeze sensitive vaccines Vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE (in the sub-district stores, OPV is kept in ILR, unlike higher level vaccine stores, where it is kept in DF) can be kept at bottom of the basket (coldest part) Vaccines should never be kept directly on the floor of the refrigerator as they can freeze and get damaged while ampoule of BCG vaccine can crack. Order in which vaccine loses its potency when exposed to heat:- Group A→ Most sensitive & Group F→ least sensitive

Vaccines sensitive to light:- BCG, measles, measles-rubella, measles-mumps-rubella and rubella. These vaccines are supplied in dark glass vials.
